evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: The Canada Orders exceed the President’s constitutional and statutory authority and violate the separation of powers.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: The imposition of universal tariffs in the Canada Orders is an unconstitutional attempt by the Executive to regulate commerce and violates Plaintiffs’ constitutional and treaty rights.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: enjoin Sections 2(a), (b), (d), (f), (g), and (h) of Executive Order 14193 as amended; Section 14 of Proclamations 10896 and 10895; and Sections 2, 3(a), (b), (c), (d), (e) (f), Section 4 (a), (b), (c), and (d) of Executive Order April 2, 2025

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: declaring Sections 2(a), (b), (d), (f), (g), and (h) of Executive Order 14193 as amended; Section 14 of Proclamations 10896 and 10895; and Sections 2, 3(a), (b), (c), (d), (e) (f), Section 4 (a), (b), (c), and (d) of Executive Order April 2, 2025 violate the of separation of powers and are unconstitutional

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: stay tariffs on all commerce and goods at the Roosville, Del Bonita, and Piegan/Carway ports of entry that are the historical ports of entry for the Kootenai and Blackfeet Tribes

extracted.value: Stay tariffs at Roosville, Piegan/Carway, and Del Bonita ports

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: It is agreed that it shall at all Times be free ... to the Indians dwelling on either side of the said Boundary Line, freely to pass and repass by Land or Inland Navigation, into the respective Territories and Countries of the Two Parties on the Continent of America ... and freely to carry on trade and commerce with each other. ... Nor shall the Indians passing or repassing with their own proper Goods and Effects of whatever nature, pay for the same any Impost or Duty whatever.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: both nations agreed to 'restore to such Tribes or Nations respectively all the possessions, rights, and privileges which they may have enjoyed or been entitled to in one thousand eight hundred and eleven previous to such hostilities.'

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Article I Section 8 Clause 1 of the Constitution gave Congress exclusive power to collect taxes and duties, and to regulate Commerce with foreign Nations, and among the several States, and with the Indian Tribes.

extracted.value: U.S. Constitution, Article I, Section 8, Clause 1

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: SEC. 105. And be it further enacted, That no duty shall be levied or collected on the importation of peltries brought into the territories of the United States, nor on the proper goods and effects, of whatever nature, of Indians passing, or repassing the boundary line aforesaid, unless the same be goods in bales or other large packages unusual among Indians, which shall not be considered as goods belonging bona fide to Indians, nor be entitled to the exemption from duty aforesaid.
